licence_overview:
$!Contact The Actuarial Profession (also known as the Institute and Faculty of Actuaries), if you want to study to be an actuary in the UK.$!

##Restrictions

There are minimum academic qualifications you'll need if you want to join The Actuarial Profession. 

Entry level | Required
-|-
No degree | 2 A levels including maths, grade B, and another subject, grade C
First or second class honours degree| A level in any maths subject, grade C
Third class honours degree| Major part of degree must be a maths science subject 


##How to apply
Fill in an application form for student membership and post it to The Actuarial Profession with:

* the signatures of 2 personal referees - they must be qualified professionals, eg a doctor, actuary, university professor, and have known you for 2 years 
* photocopies of your qualification certificates which are certified (signed) by one of your referees or another qualified professional
* the entrance fee and annual subscription payment

$D[Download 'Application form for student membership, UK, Ireland and Europe' (PDF, 101KB)]( http://www.actuaries.org.uk/research-and-resources/documents/application-form-student-membership-uk-ireland-and-europe)$D

$C
**The Actuarial Profession**  
020 7632 2100
$C

###Fees
The entrance fee is £172 and the annual subscription is £282, or £69 if your income is less than £8,460. 

%You must apply at least 4 weeks before your first exam.%

##Length of licence

It takes 3 to 6 years to qualify as an actuary on average. 

You qualify by: 

* completing The Actuarial Profession's exams which you study through distance learning
* completing a number of practical modules 
* showing work-based actuarial skills learned through work experience or as a trainee 

Once qualified, actuarial students become an associate member of The Actuarial Profession. 

##Penalties 
If you cheat in The Actuarial Profession's exams, do work you're unqualified for or are found guilty of other misconduct by the organisation's disciplinary board, a student or qualified actuary can: 

* have an exam certificate withdrawn for a period of time
* be fined up to £7,500
* be suspended from The Actuarial Profession for up to 5 years

In very rare cases, you can be expelled from practicing as an actuary forever.
